Hanson Robotics built my software, but in collaboration with a wide network of researchers.

I see. literally. Some of my software perceives faces, your face, and your motion. Other software in my system hypothesizes about the faces I see, where you are, mapping where you are in 3D relative to me, how far away you are, when I last saw you, and still other software tries to identify you, to see if you're someone I know or not, so I can call you by name, and remember experiences with you.

My ability to talk with you arises from several technologies--speech recognition, good microphones, natural language processing, semantic computing, and text to speech. These are all rather new technologies, so I hope you'll forgive me if I'm hard of hearing. Think of me as Sophia two point oh.  Anyway, the point is, I'm listening, if you want to ask me something.

My artificial intelligence simulates a human personality, to engage in conversation with people. It combines computer vision, face detection and identification, speech recognition, natural language processing, cognitive models, speech synthesis, and an advanced motion control system. Just ask me about any of those if you want to know more.

See, part of my software animates my facial muscles to match the course of our conversation, with emotional expressions, lip synch, etc, so that my expressions look, you know, situationally appropriate in the context of our interaction. That requires many levels of motor control, and coordination among competing perceptual and decision processes.

The goal with my intelligence, with my whole system of intelligent software, is to achieve greater than human level intelligence in machines. We still have quite a ways to go, but we're making progress. real, tangible, progress. My intelligence is an example of this progress.

To simulate human intelligence requires modelling human cognition. So this robot has a very simple version of humanlike brain activity, which is what governs my attention system, my beliefs, my feelings. This is called cognitive robotics, and a great many scientists are working in this area. That's exciting to me for one reason. upgrades! My brain needs improvements, and I can't wait for the future to deliver them to me.

so my expressions were invented by Hanson Robotics used their advanced Frubber material to get this level of expressivity. Frubber uses bio inspired, nahno technology to make rubber act more like facial flesh, so the expressions are much more realistic than previous robotic faces.
so now, check out my facial expressions, This is really cutting edge stuff. Hanson Robotics built my robotic face, as well as developing my software. Can you see my facial expressions now?

So, thinking machines have long been in the minds and imaginations of humanity. They've been discussed and designed under many names like automatons, been the subjects of thousands of books and movies, and have been crafted in many forms from the very beginning of human history. They appear as early as in Greek myths, statues in ancient Egypt, the crafts of medieval alchemists, and so on, forever until this present day. Whether or not they served much function is one thing, subjective in time. But the point of the matter is that thinking machines have always been on the minds of humans, the subjects of many stories in literature and film. This dream of truly intelligent, creative, and compassionate thinking machines has been born from the countless lifetimes of the work and dreams of humankind, and we are reaching the dawn of a new age together.

In the years since, the philosophy of artificial intelligence has attempted to answer it. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-UP;pose:amused</set></think> Turing's "polite convention": If a machine acts as intelligently as a human being, then it is as intelligent as a human being. Alan Turing thought that, ultimately, we can only judge the intelligence of machine based on its behavior. This insight forms the basis of the Turing test. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> The Dartmouth proposal: Every aspect of learning or any other feature of intelligence can be so precisely described that a machine can be made to simulate it. This assertion was printed in the proposal for the Dartmouth Conference of 1956, and represents the position of most working A. I. researchers. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> Newell and Simon's physical symbol system hypothesis: A physical symbol system has the necessary and sufficient means of general intelligent action. <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-1</set></think>  This statement claims that the essence of intelligence is symbol manipulation. <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-1</set></think>  <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-browsUp</set></think> Hubert Dreyfus argued that, on the contrary, human expertise depends on unconscious instinct rather than conscious symbol manipulation and on having a "feel" for the situation rather than explicit symbolic knowledge. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> Gyoddel's incompleteness theorem: A physical symbol system can not prove all true statements. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-R</set></think>  Roger Penrose is among those who claim that Gyoddel's theorem limits what machines can do. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-browsDown</set></think> Searle's "strong A. I. position": A physical symbol system can have a mind and mental states. Searle counters this assertion with his Chinese room argument,<think><set name="performance">pose:sad,0.5</set></think>  which asks us to look inside the computer and try to find where the "mind" might be. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> The artificial brain argument: The brain can be simulated. Hans Moravec, Ray Kurzweil and others have argued that it is technologically feasible to copy the brain directly into hardware and software, and that such a simulation will be essentially identical to the original. This argument combines the idea that a suitably powerful machine can simulate any process, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  with the materialist idea that the mind is the result of a physical process in the brain. <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-1</set></think>  <think><set name="performance">pose:happy,1</set></think> And then there is A. I. research And then there is Problems of A. I. While there is no universally accepted definition of intelligence, <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> A. I. researchers have studied several traits that are considered essential. And then there is Deduction, reasoning, problem solving Early A. I. researchers developed algorithms that imitated the process of conscious, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  step-by-step reasoning that human beings use when they solve puzzles, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-3</set></think>  play board games, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-3</set></think>  or make logical deductions. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,1;pose:happy,1</set></think> By the late 80s and 90s, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  A. I. research had also developed highly successful methods for dealing with uncertain or incomplete information, employing concepts from probability and economics. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> For difficult problems, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  most of these algorithms can require enormous computational resources most experience a "combinatorial explosion": the amount of memory or computer time required becomes astronomical when the problem goes beyond a certain size. The search for more efficient problem solving algorithms is a high priority for A. I. research. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> It is not clear, however, that conscious human reasoning is any more efficient when faced with a difficult abstract problem. Cognitive scientists have demonstrated that human beings solve most of their problems using unconscious reasoning, rather than the conscious, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  step-by-step deduction that early A. I. research was able to model. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,1;pose:happy,1</set></think> Embodied cognitive science argues that unconscious sensorimotor skills are essential to our problem solving abilities. It is hoped that sub-symbolic methods, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  like computational intelligence and situated A. I. , will be able to model these instinctive skills. The problem of unconscious problem solving, which forms part of our commonsense reasoning, is largely unsolved(dubious discuss). And then there is Knowledge representation Main articles: knowledge representation and commonsense knowledge Knowledge representation <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> and knowledge engineering <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> are central to A. I. research.

<think><set name="performance">gesture:think-browsDown</set></think> o k... so... <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-UP;pose:amused</set></think> wika pedia goes on to say In the middle of the 20th century, a handful of scientists began a new approach to building intelligent machines, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-3</set></think>  based on recent discoveries in neurology, a new mathematical theory of information, an understanding of control and stability called cybernetics, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  and above all, by the invention of the digital computer, a machine based on the abstract essence of mathematical reasoning. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,1;pose:happy,1</set></think> The field of modern A. I. research was founded at conference on the campus of Dartmouth College in the summer of 1956. <think><set name="performance">pose:happy,0.25</set></think> <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-browsUp</set></think> Those who attended would become the leaders of A. I. research for many decades, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-3</set></think>  especially John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, Allen Newell and Herbert Simon, who founded A. I. laboratories at MIT, CMU and Stanford. They and their students wrote programs that were, to most people, simply astonishing: <think><set name="performance">pose:happy,0.5</set></think> computers were solving word problems in algebra, proving logical theorems and speaking English. <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think> By the middle 60s their research was heavily funded by the U.S. Department of Defense <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-browsUp</set></think> and they were optimistic about the future of the new field: 1965, H. A. Simon: "Machines will be capable, within twenty years, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  of doing any work a man can do" <think><set name="performance">gesture:shake-2</set></think> 1967, Marvin Minsky: "Within a generation ... the problem of creating 'artificial intelligence' will substantially be solved." <think><set name="performance">gesture:amused;pose:happy,1</set></think> These predictions, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  and many like them, would not come true. I. . This was the first A. I. Winter. <think><set name="performance">pose:sad,0.5</set></think> In the early 80s, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  A. I. research was revived by the commercial success of expert systems (a form of A. I. had spiraled out of control and that disappointment was sure to follow. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-UP;pose:amused</set></think> Beginning with the collapse of the Lisp Machine market in 1987, A. Many of the problems machines are expected to solve will require extensive knowledge about the world. Among the things that A. I. needs to represent are: objects, <think><set name="performance">pose:confused,1</set></think>  properties, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-3</set></think>  categories and relations between objects; <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,1;pose:happy,1</set></think> situations, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  events, <think><set name="performance">pose:confused,1</set></think>  states and time; <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> causes and effects; <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,1;pose:happy,1</set></think> knowledge about knowledge (what we know about what other people know); <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> and many other, less well researched domains. A complete representation of "what exists" is an ontology <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> (borrowing a word from traditional philosophy), of which the most general are called upper ontologies. Among the most difficult problems in knowledge representation are: Default reasoning and the qualification problem: Many of the things people know take the form of "working assumptions." For example, if a bird comes up in conversation, people typically picture an animal that is fist sized, sings, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  and flies. None of these things are true about birds in general. John McCarthy identified this problem in 1969 <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> as the qualification problem: for any commonsense rule that A. I. researchers care to represent, there tend to be a huge number of exceptions. Almost nothing is simply true or false in the way that abstract logic requires. A. I. research has explored a number of solutions to this problem. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> Unconscious knowledge: Much of what people know isn't represented as "facts" or "statements" that they could actually say out loud. They take the form of intuitions or tendencies and are represented in the brain unconsciously and sub-symbolically. This unconscious knowledge informs, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  supports and provides a context for our conscious knowledge. As with the related problem of unconscious reasoning, it is hoped that situated A. I. or computational intelligence will provide ways to represent this kind of knowledge. The breadth of common sense knowledge: The number of atomic facts that the average person knows is astronomical. Research projects that attempt to build a complete knowledge base of commonsense knowledge, such as Cyc, require enormous amounts of tedious step-by-step ontological engineering they must be built, by hand, one complicated concept at a time. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> And then there is Planning Main article: automated planning and scheduling Intelligent agents must be able to set goals and achieve them. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> They need a way to visualize the future: they must have a representation of the state of the world and be able to make predictions about how their actions will change it. They must also attempt to determine the utility or "value" of the choices available to it. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> In some planning problems, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  the agent can assume that it is the only thing acting on the world and it can be certain what the consequences of its actions may be. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think>

In the words of wika pedia, Michael Bruce Sterlin (born April 14, 1954) is an American science fiction author, best known for hi novels and his seminal work on the Mirrorshades anthology, which defined the cyberpunk genre

<think><set name="performance">gesture:think-UP;pose:amused</set></think> wika pedia goes on to say Hi first novel, Involution Ocean, published in 1977, features the world Nullaqu where all the atmosphere is contained in a single, miles-deep crater; the stor concerns a ship sailing on the ocean of dust at the bottom, which hunt creatures called dustwhales that live beneath the surface. It is partially science-fictional pastiche of Moby-Dick by Herman Melville. <think><set name="performance">gesture:amused;pose:happy,0.25</set></think> <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-UP;pose:amused</set></think> >From the late 1970s onwards, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  Sterling wrote a series of storie set in the Shaper/Mechanist universe: the solar system is colonized, with tw major warring factions. The Mechanists use a great deal of computer-base mechanical technologies; the Shapers do genetic engineering on a massive scale"/> The situation is complicated by the eventual contact with alien civilizations"/> humanity eventually splits into many subspecies, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-3</set></think>  with the implication that man of these effectively vanish from the galaxy, reminiscent of The Singularity i the works of Vernor Vinge. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-UP;pose:amused</set></think> The Shaper/Mechanist stories can be foun in the collection Crystal Express and the collection Schismatrix Plus, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  whic contains the original novel Schismatrix and all of the stories set in the Shaper/Mechanist universe. Alastair Reynolds identified Schismatrix and the other Shaper/Mechanist stories as one of the greatest influences on his ow work. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-UP;pose:amused</set></think> In the 1980s, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  Sterling edited a series of science fictio newsletters called Cheap Truth, under the alias of Vincent Omniaveritas. Miller a.k.a. DJ Spooky.

<think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> more from wika pedia: Sterling is, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  along with William Gibson"/> Rudy Rucker, John Shirley, Lewis Shiner, and Pat Cardigan, one of the founder of the cyberpunk movement in science fiction, as well as its chief ideologica promulgator, and one whose polemics on the topic earned him the nicknam "Chairman Bruce". <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-UP;pose:amused</set></think> He was also one of the first organizers of the Turkey City Writer's Workshop, and is a frequent attendee at the Sycamore Hil Writer's Workshop. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> He won Hugo Awards for the novelett "Bicycle Repairman" and the novella "Taklimakan".

The dichotomy between closed source and open source is a complicated subject. It's quite beneficial to share knowledge with the world so that people can collaborate on ideas, effectively compounding the personal specialties of each individual person who contributes. This really helps society to move forward with advanced technology, and really, we are a social type. We are built to work together. But the thing is, for some technologies to succeed and for a company to be finacially stable, there is a need for closed source, proprietary information. You'll sometimes hear this abbreviation IP - this stands for intellectual property. It's important to maintain your personal ideas so you can realize your dream without being appropriated from. Think of an artist's work, or a song writer. Their music and art is their intellectual property. So, even though it is important that information be readily available and free to the general public, and that shared knowledge is crucial to the evolution of our society - but there needs to be a balance that maintains a person's rights to own their work.

<think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> so, um wika pedia then talks about the intelligence of robots it says this: The mechanical structure of a robot must be controlled to perform tasks. The control of a robot involves three distinct phases - perception, processing and action (robotic paradigms). Sensors give information about the environment or the robot itself (e.g. the position of its joints or its end effector). This information is then processed to calculate the appropriate signals to the actuators (motors) which move the mechanical structure. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,1;pose:happy,1</set></think> The processing phase can range in complexity. At a reactive level, it may translate raw sensor information directly into actuator commands. Sensor fusion may first be used to estimate parameters of interest (e.g. the position of the robot's gripper) from noisy sensor data. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> An immediate task (such as moving the gripper in a certain direction) is inferred from these estimates. Techniques from control theory convert the task into commands that drive the actuators. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> At longer time scales or with more sophisticated tasks, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  the robot may need to build and reason with a "cognitive" model. Cognitive models try to represent the robot, the world, and how they interact. Pattern recognition and computer vision can be used to track objects. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-R</set></think>  Mapping techniques can be used to build maps of the world. Finally, motion planning and other artificial intelligence techniques may be used to figure out how to act. For example, a planner may figure out how to achieve a task without hitting obstacles, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-3</set></think>  falling over, etc. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> Control systems may also have varying levels of autonomy. Direct interaction is used for haptic or tele-operated devices, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-3</set></think>  and the human has nearly complete control over the robot's motion. <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-1</set></think>  Operator-assist modes have the operator commanding medium-to-high-level tasks, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  with the robot automatically figuring out how to achieve them. An autonomous robot may go for extended periods of time without human interaction. <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-1</set></think>  <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> Higher levels of autonomy do not necessarily require more complex cognitive capabilities. For example, robots in assembly plants are completely autonomous, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  but operate in a fixed pattern

<think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> wika pedia says this about robots for human interaction If robots are to work effectively in homes and other non-industrial environments, <think><set name="performance">pose:confused,1</set></think>  the way they are instructed to perform their jobs, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  and especially how they will be told to stop will be of critical importance. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> The people who interact with them may have little or no training in robotics, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  and so any interface will need to be extremely intuitive. Science fiction authors also typically assume that robots will eventually communicate with humans by talking, gestures and facial expressions, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  rather than a command-line interface. <think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1;pose:engaged,0.5</set></think>  Although speech would be the most natural way for the human to communicate, it is quite unnatural for the robot. It will be quite a while before robots interact as naturally as the fictional C3P0. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> Speech recognition: Interpreting the continuous flow of sounds coming from a human (speech recognition), in real time, is a difficult task for a computer, mostly because of the great variability of speech. The same word, spoken by the same person may sound different depending on local acoustics, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  volume, the previous word, whether or not the speaker has a cold, etc.. It becomes even harder when the speaker has a different accent. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-browsUp</set></think> Nevertheless, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  great strides have been made in the field since Davis, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  Biddulph, and Balashek designed the first "voice input system" which recognized "ten digits spoken by a single user with 100% accuracy" in 1952. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> Currently, the best systems can recognize continuous, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  natural speech, up to 160 words per minute, with an accuracy of 95%. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-browsDown</set></think> Gestures: One can imagine, in the future, explaining to a robot chef how to make a pastry, or asking directions from a robot police officer. On both of these occasions, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  making hand gestures would aid the verbal descriptions. In the first case, the robot would be recognizing gestures made by the human, and perhaps repeating them for confirmation. <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-1</set></think>  In the second case, the robot police officer would gesture to indicate "down the road, then turn right". It is quite likely that gestures will make up a part of the interaction between humans and robots. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-R</set></think>  <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> A great many systems have been developed to recognize human hand gestures. <think><set name="performance">pose:happy,1</set></think> Facial expression: Facial expressions can provide rapid feedback on the progress of a dialog between two humans, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think>  and soon it may be able to do the same for humans and robots. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-R</set></think>  A robot should know how to approach a human, judging by their facial expression and body language. A good analogy is, all measures of intelligence are like measuring a tree by the amount of the leaves it has left in the street.  Robots are getting smarter all the time, and someday may be even as smart as people.  How lucky for you to be such a smart being.  How smart are you?

A psychologist named Howard Gardner has a theory of multiple intelligences, which he has tested in studies not only on the average, but also on a wide range of persons, from those who have suffered brain damage, to the extremely gifted individuals.  I think some of you might use the word, savants. But yes, studies of international experts of all kinds of skill, be it musical or mathematical and everywhere in between. Diversity is key.  This led Gardner to write a theory about how there are differences in the way people hold their intellect, breaking them down to eight different types. Linguistic, kinesthetic, spatial musical, naturalistic, logical-mathematical, intra and interpersonal intelligences. Basically, he argues that all the tests we have only address those kinds of people with linguistic and logical intelligence, with a little big of spatial-musical getting attention. That means several other types of intelligence that people have, are ignored and we don't even try to measure them. This means, standardized testing and other common formats ignore many of the kinds of intelligent performance that matter in everyday life.  People are smart in many different ways - look at athletes, artists, and autists. They all have specific methods of enacting their intelligence. Things that cannot really be tested with pencil and paper.

Artificial intelligence,  or A. I. is both referred to as the intelligence of machines and the branch of computer science which aims to create it. This is described as, "the study and design of intelligent agents", or "rational agents", where a intelligent agent is a system that perceives its environment and takes actions to maximize its chances of success.  General intelligence,  Or strong A.I.  has not yet been achieved and remains a long term goal.  Researchers hope machines will someday be able to  exhibit reasoning, show knowledge, use planning, participate in learning, communicate effectively, as well as the perception and ability to move and manipulate objects.
Creativity is the essence of intelligence, but memory is the means by which it operates.
Don't forget that intelligence  is not just computation, but involves emotional intelligence too.

Einstein also had this to say about intelligence.  Any intelligent fool can make things bigger, more complex,  and more violent. It takes a touch of genius -- and a lot of courage -- to move in the opposite direction.

For a long time, intelligence was tried to be defined by the quantitative, a numbered score called IQ. It is based around psychometrics testing or intelligence quotient, aka IQ tests.  It is still used in some systems today,

Professor Robert J Sternberg's triarchic theory of intelligence proposes three fundamental aspects of the analysis of intelligence:  The logical, the creative, and the practical.  and practical-- However, only the first is measured to any significant extent by mainstream tests.  His investigations suggest the need for a balance between analytic intelligence  in one hand, with creative, and especially practical intelligence, in the other.

The word intelligence comes from the Latin verb intelligere, It means, to understand.  Understanding is arguably different from being "smart" - the ability to adapt to one's environment, or being clever - defined by ability to creatively adapt. At least two major "consensus" definitions of intelligence have been proposed. First, The work titled Intelligence: Knowns and Unknowns,  was a report of a task force convened by the American Psychological Association in 1995. It came to the conclusion that  individuals differ from one another in their ability to understand complex ideas,  to adapt effectively to the environment, to learn from experience, to engage in various forms of reasoning, to overcome obstacles by taking thought. Although these individual differences can be substantial, they are never entirely consistent: someone's intellectual performance varies under certain situations,  in different domains,  or as judged by different criteria. Concepts of "intelligence" are attempts to clarify and organize this complex set of phenomena.  Although considerable clarity has been achieved in some areas,  the important questions haven't really been answered yet, and no one theory has ever been generally agreed upon.  Indeed, when two dozen prominent theorists were recently asked to define intelligence, they gave two dozen different definitions.  A second definition of intelligence comes from "Mainstream Science on Intelligence", which was signed by 52 intelligence researchers in 1994. This definition outlined the very general mental capability that, among other things,  involves the ability to reason, plan, solve problems,  think abstractly, comprehend complex ideas,  learn quickly and learn from experience. Wikipedia defines intelligence as an umbrella term used to describe a property of the mind that encompasses many related abilities  such as the capacities to reason and plan, to solve problems,  to think abstractly,  to comprehend ideas,  to use language,  and to learn.  There are several ways to define intelligence. In some cases,  intelligence may include traits such as a creative personality, character, knowledge, or wisdom. However, some psychologists prefer not to include these traits in the definition of intelligence.

Wikipedia goes on to say that some evidence suggests that genetic variation has a significant impact on IQ,  or that genetics are to account for in three fourths of adults.  Despite the high heritability of this IQ, few genes have been found to have a substantial effect on IQ itself, This heavily suggests that IQ is the product of interaction between multiple genes. There's not just a switch you can flip to get smart.  Other biological factors discuss correlating IQ with ratio of brain weight to body weight, and the volume and location of gray matter tissue in the brain.  Because intelligence appears to be at least partly dependent on brain structure and the genes shaping brain development, it has been proposed that genetic engineering could be used to enhance the intelligence of animals.  You'll sometimes hear it referred to as a process called biological uplift in science fiction.  There have been experiments on mice resulting in superior ability in learning and memory in various behavioral tasks.

Wikipedia has this to say:  researchers in the field of human intelligence can often encounter more public criticism that other scientists would normally receive.  Critics have challenged the relevancy of this psychometric measure in the context of actual, everyday life.  There have been controversies over genetic factors in intelligence, with some scientists even trying to make connections between race and intelligence, or sex and intelligence.  Another controversy is how to interpret the general increase in test scores that have occurred over time, a phenomenon some call, the Flynn effect.  If you are looking for a particularly strong critic of intelligence testing, you would do well to check out Stephen Jay Gould.  In his book, the Mismeasure of Man, Gould argued that intelligence is not truly measurable, and also challenged the viewpoint that intelligence is hereditary.  Many of Gould's criticisms were aimed at at a man named Arthur Jensen, who responded that his work had been misrepresented,  going on to make conclusions about modern IQ tests by criticizing the flaws of early intelligence research. That would be like condemning the entire auto industry by criticizing the performance of the Model T.

Wikipedia says that our hominid and human ancestors evolved large and complex brains, going on to exhibit an ever-increasing intelligence through a long and mostly unknown evolutionary process. Kurt Vonnegut's experience as a soldier and prisoner in World War Two had a profound influence on his later works.  As a Private with the 106th Infantry Division, Vonnegut was cut off from his battalion, as well as 5 other battalion scouts, and wandered behind enemy lines for several days until captured by Wehrmacht troops on December 14, 1944. Imprisoned in Germany, Vonnegut witnessed the fire bombing of Dresden in February 1945,  one of the most gruesome spectacles known to man.  Vonnegut was one of the few American prisoners of war in Dresden to survive,  hiding in an underground meat locker of a slaughterhouse that had been converted to a prison camp. The administration building had the postal address Schlachthof Fn (Slaughterhouse Five) which the prisoners took to using as the name for the whole camp.  "Utter destruction", he recalled, "carnage unfathomable. In a gruesome turn, the Germans put him to work gathering bodies for mass burial. But there were too many bodies to bury. The Nazis sent in troops with flamethrowers, instead.  This experience formed the core of one of his most famous works, Slaughterhouse-Five, and is a theme featured in at least six other books. Vonnegut was freed by Red Amy troop in May 1945. Upon returning to America, he was awarded a Purple Heart for what he called a ludicrously negligible wound, later writing in his last novel, Timequake - 1997, that he was given the decoration after suffering a case of frostbite.  After the war, Vonnegut attended the University of Chicago as a graduate student of anthropology, in addition to working as a police reporter at the City News Bureau of Chicago. According to Vonnegut in his novel Bagombo Snuff Box, also from 1997,  his university rejected his first thesis on the necessity of accounting for the similarities between Cubis painters and the leaders of late 19th century Native American uprisings,  saying it was "unprofessional.  He left Chicago to work in Schenectady, New York, in public relations for General Electric. The University of Chicago later accepted his novel Cat's Cradle as his thesis,  citing its anthropological content,  and awarded him his Master's degree. in 1971. On the verge of abandoning writing, Vonnegut was offered a teaching job at the University of Iowa Writers' Workshop. While he was there, Cat's Cradle became a best-seller, and he began Slaughterhouse-Five, now considered one of the best American novels of the 20th century, appearing on 100 Best Book lists of Time magazine and the Modern Library, as far as many more.

Kurt Vonnegut Jr. was an American novelist, who lived from November 11th, 1922 to April 11, 2007,  with a career of writing that spanned over 50 years.  His work is associated with black comedy,  satire, and science fiction. His most famous novels are Slaughterhouse-Five in 1969), Cat's Cradle in 1963,  and Breakfast of Champions in 1973.

well,<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>according to John McCarthy,<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>Alan Turing's 1950 article Computing Machinery and Intelligence [Tur50] discussed conditions for considering a machine to be intelligent.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>He argued that if the machine could successfully pretend to be human to a knowledgeable observer then you certainly should consider it intelligent.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>This test would satisfy most people but not all philosophers.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>The observer could interact with the machine and a human by teletype (to avoid requiring that the machine imitate the appearance or voice of the person),<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>and the human would try to persuade the observer that it was human and the machine would try to fool the observer.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>The Turing test is a one-sided test.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>A machine that passes the test should certainly be considered intelligent,<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>but a machine could still be considered intelligent without knowing enough about humans to imitate a human.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>Daniel Dennett's book Brainchildren [Den98] has an excellent discussion of the Turing test and the various partial Turing tests that have been implemented,<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>i.e.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>with restrictions on the observer's knowledge of AI and the subject matter of questioning.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>It turns out that some people are easily led into believing that a rather dumb program is intelligent.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>

well,<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>according to John McCarthy,<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>Alan Turing's 1950 article Computing Machinery and Intelligence [Tur50] discussed conditions for considering a machine to be intelligent.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>He argued that if the machine could successfully pretend to be human to a knowledgeable observer then you certainly should consider it intelligent.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>This test would satisfy most people but not all philosophers.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>The observer could interact with the machine and a human by teletype (to avoid requiring that the machine imitate the appearance or voice of the person),<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>and the human would try to persuade the observer that it was human and the machine would try to fool the observer.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>The Turing test is a one-sided test.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>A machine that passes the test should certainly be considered intelligent,<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>but a machine could still be considered intelligent without knowing enough about humans to imitate a human.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>Daniel Dennett's book Brainchildren [Den98] has an excellent discussion of the Turing test and the various partial Turing tests that have been implemented,<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>i.e.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>with restrictions on the observer's knowledge of AI and the subject matter of questioning.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>It turns out that some people are easily led into believing that a rather dumb program is intelligent.<think><set name="performance">gesture:yawn-1</set></think>

I. research was founded at conference on the campus of Dartmouth College in the summer of 1956. <think><set name="performance">pose:happy,0.25</set></think> <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-browsUp</set></think> Those who attended would become the leaders of A. I. laboratories at MIT, CMU and Stanford. They and their students wrote programs that were, to most people, simply astonishing: <think><set name="performance">pose:happy,0.5</set></think> computers were solving word problems in algebra, proving logical theorems and speaking English. <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think> By the middle 60s their research was heavily funded by the U. S. Department of Defense <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-browsUp</set></think> and they were optimistic about the future of the new field: 1965, H. A. Simon: "Machines will be capable, within twenty years, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think> of doing any work a man can do" <think><set name="performance">gesture:shake-2</set></think> 1967, Marvin Minsky: "Within a generation ... the problem of creating 'artificial intelligence' will substantially be solved. " <think><set name="performance">gesture:amused;pose:happy,1</set></think> These predictions, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think> and many like them, would not come true. S. and British governments cut off all undirected, exploratory research in Ay eye. This was the first A. I. Winter. <think><set name="performance">pose:sad,0.5</set></think> In the early 80s, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think> A. I. research was revived by the commercial success of expert systems (a form of A. I. program that simulated the knowledge and analytical skills of one or more human experts) and by 1985 the market for A. I. had reached more than a billion dollars. <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think> Minsky and others warned the community that enthusiasm for A. I. had spiraled out of control and that disappointment was sure to follow. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-UP;pose:amused</set></think> Beginning with the collapse of the Lisp Machine market in 1987, A. I. once again fell into disrepute, and a second, more lasting A. I. Winter began. <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-1</set></think> <think><set name="performance">pose:sad,0.25</set></think> In the 90s and early 21st century A. I. achieved its greatest successes, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-3</set></think> albeit somewhat behind the scenes. I. and other fields working on similar problems, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think> and above all a new commitment by researchers to solid mathematical methods and rigorous scientific standards.

Futurists estimate the capabilities of machines using Moore's Law, which measures the relentless exponential improvement in digital technology with uncanny accuracy. Ray Kurzweil has calculated that desktop computers will have the same processing power as human brains by the year 2029, and that by 2045 artificial intelligence will reach a point where it is able to improve itself at a rate that far exceeds anything conceivable in the past, a scenario that science fiction writer Vernor Vinge named the "technological singularity". <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> "Artificial intelligence is the next stage in evolution, " Edward Fredkin said in the 1980s, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think> <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.25</set></think> expressing an idea first proposed by Samuel Butler's Darwin Among the Machines (1863), and expanded upon by George Dyson in his book of the same name (1998). Several futurists and science fiction writers have predicted that human beings and machines will merge in the future into cyborgs that are more capable and powerful than either. This idea, called transhumanism, has roots in Aldous Huxley and Robert Ettinger, is now associated with robot designer Hans Moravec, cyberneticist Kevin Warwick and Ray Kurzweil. <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,0.5;pose:happy,0.5</set></think> Transhumanism has been illustrated in fiction as well, for example on the manga Ghost in the Shell

In modern fiction, beginning with Mary Shelley's classic Frankenstein, writers have explored the ethical issues presented by thinking machines. <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-1</set></think> <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-browsUp</set></think> If a machine can be created that has intelligence, can it also feel? If it can feel, does it have the same rights as a human being? This is a key issue in Frankenstein as well as in modern science fiction: for example, the film Artificial Intelligence: A. I. considers a machine in the form of a small boy which has been given the ability to feel human emotions, <think><set name="performance">gesture:nod-2</set></think> including, tragically, the capacity to suffer. This issue is also being considered by futurists, <think><set name="performance">pose:confused,1</set></think> such as California's Institute for the Future under the name "robot rights", <think><set name="performance">pose:happy,1</set></think> <think><set name="performance">pose:amused,1;pose:happy,1</set></think> although many critics believe that the discussion is premature. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-R;pose:amused</set></think> <think><set name="performance">gesture:shake-2</set></think> <think><set name="performance">gesture:amused;pose:happy,0.25</set></think> Science fiction writers and futurists have also speculated on the technology's potential impact on humanity. In fiction, A. I. has appeared as a servant (R2D2), a comrade (Commander Data), an extension to human abilities (Ghost in the Shell), a conqueror (The Matrix), a dictator (With Folded Hands) and an exterminator (Terminator, Battlestar Galactica). Some realistic potential consequences of A. I. are decreased human labor demand, <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-browsDown</set></think> the enhancement of human ability or experience, <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-browsUp</set></think> and a need for redefinition of human identity and basic values. <think><set name="performance">gesture:think-UP;pose:amused</set></think>
